Make a vase and flowers
Here\'s what you need:
Make Flowers and Vase
Make a vase and flowers with ordinary materials!
-Empty Plastic Water Bottle-
-Straws-
-Thin paper, such as tissue paper. Cloth-like plastic works well, too.-
-Stapler or Glue-
Cut curved part of bottle off. Have an older child or adult help with this step. A taller vase will be less likely to tip over.
Cut a square shape (about 8" x 8") out of tissue paper. Perfection is not necessary.
Fold paper in half, corner to corner, to make a triangle.
Fold again in half corner to corner.
Fold 2 more times the same way.
Trim long edge of triangle as shown.
Trim corners into curved shape.
Pinch point opposite of long edge to crinkle paper.
Apply glue to pinched end.
Insert end tightly into straw. Don\'t worry if you crush your flower a little during this step, you will fluff it up later.
Let dry according to glue instructions.
Gently separate layers of paper so that the flower appears fuller.
Make additional flowers as desired.
Arrange flowers into vase.

Optional: You may wish to decorate your vase by creating a design on paper, then taping the paper around the vase or you can glue sequins and yard to vase. You can place stones in the base of the vase to prevent tipping.
Make a Minecraft Pig Megalith
Make a Pig Megalith in Minecraft!
This tutorial assumes that you have the game Minecraft and are familiar with using it.
Use a magenta stained clay block. Make a single row of 15 blocks.
From each side, create a partial second row. Add 4 blocks of magenta stained clay blocks on each side.
Fill in the middle of this row with 7 pink stained clay blocks. Add another row of 7 pink on top of this row of 7.

Above this row, add 2 gray stained clay block from each side. Add another row of 2 on top of each gray row. Fill in the middle of the gray blocks with purple stained clay blocks. Top that row with 2 rows of pink stained clay blocks.
Fill in sides up to top of snout with magenta stained clay blocks.
Starting with the left edge on the next row, place 2 black stained clay blocks. Stack 2 more rows on top of that for a total of 6 black stained blocks. Repeat on the other side of the row.
Fill in toward the center 2 blocks of quartz, and stack 3 high, same total size as the black blocks. Repeat on the other side.
Fill in between the eyes with magenta blocks.
Place 2 rows of magenta stained clay blocks over the eye rows and you are finished!
Make a Steel Drum

Make a steel drum with ordinary materials! This is a project you can do for a younger child or an older child may be able to do some of the steps by themselves. Close supervision should be used on this project.
-Large can with a soft metal bottom and removable lid-
-2 Unsharpened pencils-
-2 rubber bands-
-A small mallet or something suitable for pounding-
-Rock or other hard item with a large flat (not sharp) edge. Adults or older children should handle this item. You can experiment with different items to see which works best for you.-
Prepare your can by washing and removing label if necessary. Soaking the can in water may help with this step.
Make your drumsticks (aka Mallets) by wrapping a rubber band around the eraser part of each pencil. You may use multiple rubber bands to make a bigger mallet head.
Place can on a flat surface and begin by hammering down a section of the flat metal side of can. You should hammer a soft trapezoid shape from the edge. Take a look at the picture before starting.
Gently hammer the reverse of the trapezoid out (from inside the can), then flip over and make sure the trapezoid line is still pressed down.
Test with your homemade drumsticks to see if the pitch is different from the trapezoid part to the main part. If it\'s not, you may need to work the reverse side again.
Make another trapezoid of a different size next to the one you created, and hammer it out from the inside again to make another section.
Keep making new sections of different sizes until all the space is filled with sections.
Any leftover middle section can be hammered in or out, depending upon the sound you prefer. Keep tinkering with the different sections until you acheive a sound you like.
You may wish to play your drum in the crook of your arm so the sound can resonate out of the bottom of the drum. Experiment with different ways to make the sound.
Congratulations! You\'ve made a steel drum!
Make an Acorn Whistle
Create a whistle from an acorn cap. All you need to do is explore outside to find an oak tree, and you will likely find acorns or acorn caps.
-Acorn cap-
-Your hands!-
Gather a few acorn caps from your neighborhood or forest preserve. They should be in good shape with minimal to no knicks along the edge.
Place your thumbs over the open portion of the cap so that your knuckles meet in the middle (and are bent) and forming a \"V\" shape. The bottom of the V should be in the center of the cap.
Put your bottom lip on your knuckles, firm up your lips, and blow. You may need to experiment with where you place your thumbs, lips, and the angle of the acorn cap to get the best sound.
Congratulations! You can now play an acorn whistle!
Make a Lego Mini-House
Use your Lego bricks to create a tiny house!
Place the 2 large green bricks side by side.
Place 3 gray bricks as shown.
Place down your lamp and tree as shown.
Make the garage by placing the 2 by 2 brick at the end of the driveway and topping it with the gray piece as shown.
Make the foundation for your house by placing the 1 by 4 bricks as shown below.
Use the 1 by 6 bricks to create the front of the house.
Add the roof of the garage by using 2 wedge-shaped pieces.
Place a 2 by 2 brick in the middle of the front of the house, and a wedge brick on each side.
Place 2 more wedge bricks together on top of the house, then top with an antenna and your house is complete. Congratulations! You\'ve made a tiny Lego house!
